awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Intracellular Survival Strategies of Amoeba-Resistant Bacteria
awd_abstract_narration:
The interaction between amoebae and bacteria is one of oldest predator-prey relationships in nature and a major driving force for bacterial diversity, persistence, and pathogenesis. The amoebae ingest the bacteria and enclose them in a compartment for degradation. The bacterium Legionella pneumophila resists degradation by changing the membrane-bound compartment so that it can proliferate. This intracellular survival strategy is common to many bacteria, however, the mechanisms that underlie this strategy are not well understood. The research supported by this award will define the molecular mechanisms through which Legionella controls and manipulates the eukaryotic cell and resists degradation. This information will lead to novel insights into how bacteria are able to survive within eukaryotic cells, including immune cells such as macrophages. As such, this research has the potential to provide a better understanding of bacterial pathogenesis.  The educational goal of this project is to stimulate interest in science at multiple educational levels with a focus on retention of students from underrepresented minority groups. This goal will be accomplished by partnering with the Upward Bound Math/Science program at the University of Delaware to stimulate enthusiasm for scientific research by providing high school students with authentic research experiences, developing a research-based module to enhance the current undergraduate microbiology curriculum at the University of Delaware, and developing and implementing interactive materials and hands on activities for families attending the Delaware Children's Museum. Since diverse undergraduate and graduate students will participate in these community outreach activities, children will observe that people of various ages and ethnicities can be scientists. This project is co-funded by the Symbiosis, Defense, Self-recognition Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems and by the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research.

In nature, amoebae ingest bacteria by phagocytosis, and once internalized, bacteria remain enclosed in a plasma membrane-derived compartment that is destined for degradation by fusion with lysosomes. However, L. pneumophila remodels the cytosolic surface of the vacuolar membrane to avoid degradation. The integrity and remodeling of the vacuole is critical for survival of L. pneumophila and its establishment requires the activity of bacterial proteins delivered into the host cell via a specialized secretion system. The overarching hypothesis of this project is that remodeling of the replication-permissive vacuole depends on the bacterium's ability to target and regulate host membrane trafficking. The principal investigator will apply microbiological, biochemical, and cell biological approaches to determine the molecular mechanisms that bacterial proteins use to selectively target host vesicles in order to promote bacterial survival. The focus is on refining our understanding of how bacterial proteins manipulate the activity of two key components that regulate host vesicular traffic: Rab GTPase proteins and phosphoinositide lipids. Results obtained here will advance the field of host-microbe interactions by further defining how free-living bacteria can acquire the capacity to grow within eukaryotic cells. The project will provide educational opportunities for URM high-school and undergraduate students and will facilitate interactions between students and the local community through outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to gain deeper insight into the mechanisms that enable free-living bacteria to survive and even thrive in eukaryotic cells. Our model system, Legionella pneumophila, is a Gram-negative facultative intracellular bacterium found in soil and aquatic environments. Having co-evolved with microbe-grazing amoebae in these environments, Legionella developed strategies to resist degradation and instead convert the predatory amoebae into replication-permissive hosts. As evolutionary precursors of macrophages, amoebae serve as environmental hosts driving evolution of human pathogens. This work aimed to expand fundamental understanding of the molecular mechanisms Legionella employs to exploit and survive within eukaryotic host cells.  Upon engulfment, Legionella establishes a membrane-bound compartment where it can safely multiply. Biogenesis and maintenance of the vacuole depends on proteins secreted by Legionella into  the host cell. The hypothesis was that Legionella deploys proteins that selectively target key regulators of host membrane trafficking pathways. The project focused on identifying and characterizing bacterial proteins that allow Legionella to recognize and manipulate eukaryotic membrane compartments. 

Results revealed that Legionella employs an extensive repertoire of effector proteins that bind phosphoinositides, a class of lipids known to function as key regulators of membrane trafficking through recruitment and activation of protein complexes. Biochemical and cell biological assays demonstrated that most the newly identified phosphoinositide-binding effectors preferentially recognize PI(3)P, one of seven known types of phosphoinositides. Moreover, bioinformatic analyses comparing their predicted structures revealed distinct folds shared among these lipid-binding bacterial proteins. Functional characterization of several PI(3)P-binding Legionella effector proteins revealed a propensity for targeting autophagy, an evolutionarily conserved pathway that supports cellular function and homeostasis by recycling cellular components and removing damaged organelles, protein aggregates, and pathogens. Furthermore, two of the phosphoinositide-binding effectors translocated at the later stages of infection were found to associate with host mitochondria. This work not only sheds light on Legionella's manipulation of host cellular processes but also provides a framework for exploring similar mechanisms in related bacterial species, broadening our insights into the evolution and diversity of host-microbe dynamics.

The educational goal of this project was to inspire a passion for science across diverse educational levels, with a strong emphasis on supporting and empowering students from underrepresented minority groups. This goal was achieved through a variety of impactful educational activities. In collaboration with the Upward Bound Math/Science program, over 50 students from local high school participated in authentic research experiences. Every member of the PI's research team contributed to mentoring and guiding these students through hands-on research projects. The award also facilitated public outreach by creating and implementing interactive materials and hands-on activities for families visiting the Delaware Children's Museum, engaging more than 250 children and parents in community science events. Furthermore, a research-based module was developed to enrich the undergraduate microbiology curriculum at the University of Delaware.

Intellectual merit
This work has deepened our understanding of how intracellular bacteria exploit host resources to support their survival and replication. The findings offer valuable insights into the strategies that enable free-living bacteria to persist within eukaryotic cells. The discovery of an extensive repertoire of phosphoinositide-binding proteins utilized by Legionella to manipulate host membrane trafficking highlights the potential for a broader paradigm in understanding how intravacuolar bacteria recognize and interact with host membranes.


Broader impact
The research funded by this award has made significant contributions to the field of host-microbe interactions by uncovering fundamental bacterial strategies for intracellular survival in eukaryotic hosts. These insights have not only advanced our understanding of microbial pathogenesis but also hold potential to inform therapeutic approaches for Legionella and related human pathogens, ultimately benefiting public health. In addition to its scientific impact, this project has fostered meaningful educational and public outreach initiatives, connecting research with the broader community. By engaging students  in research and outreach activities, the project emphasized the value of contributing to both science and society. These efforts provided students with a holistic experience, helping them to build a stronger sense of scientific identity while developing critical skills in inquiry and collaboration. Collectively, these broader impacts underscore the dual mission of advancing scientific knowledge while empowering future generations of scientists and engaging the public in the scientific endeavor.


Last Modified: 12/12/2024
Modified by: Maria R Neunuebel
